questions.text: A 51-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a persistent cough and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss over the past 2 months. Yesterday, she coughed up bloody sputum. She does not smoke. Pulmonary examination shows decreased breath sounds over the right upper lobe. A CT scan of the chest shows a mass in the periphery of the right upper lobe. Histopathologic examination of a specimen obtained on CT-guided biopsy shows glandular cells with papillary components and signet ring cells that stain positive for mucin. An activating mutation of which of the following genes is most likely to have occurred in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The BRAF gene is a proto-oncogene, but mutations in BRAF are associated with small cell lung cancer, not non-small cell lung cancers like lung adenocarcinoma. Moreover, these mutations are usually associated with a history of smoking.

B) INCORRECT:

Most types of cancer are associated with mutations in the TP53 gene. However, since TP53 is a tumor suppressor gene rather than a proto-oncogene, there would have to be a loss-of-function mutation rather than an activating mutation for cancer to develop.

C) CORRECT:

Chromosomal translocation of the ALK gene results in the fusion oncogene EML4-ALK, which leads to lung adenocarcinoma. This translocation occurs more frequently in nonsmokers and patients younger than 65 years of age. In addition, signet ring cells are more likely to be seen in lung adenocarcinomas with the EML4-ALK oncogene than those without it. Activating mutations in the EGFR gene and KRAS gene can also cause lung adenocarcinoma. Testing the biopsy specimen for activation of these genes can help predict the efficacy of targeted therapy (e.g., ALK inhibitors, EGFR inhibitors).

See “Overview of proto-oncogenes” table.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung tissue sample (H&E stain; 400x magnification)

Several confluent tubular glands lined by atypical epithelium (examples indicated by green outline) and surrounded by desmoplastic hypercellular stroma are visible. There is nuclear stratification (nuclei located at different heights within the epithelium rather than basally only), nuclear hyperchromasia (darker stained nuclei), and pleomorphism (different sizes of cells and nuclei).

These are typical findings in acinar adenocarcinoma of the lung.

D) INCORRECT:

The APC gene is a tumor suppressor gene, not a proto-oncogene. Mutations in the APC gene are associated with colorectal cancer (in particular, familial adenomatous polyposis), not lung adenocarcinoma.

E) INCORRECT:

The SMAD4 (DPC4) gene is a tumor suppressor gene, not a proto-oncogene. Mutations in this gene are associated with the development of pancreatic cancer, not lung adenocarcinoma.

F) INCORRECT:

The MYCL1 gene is a proto-oncogene, but mutations in MYCL1 are associated with about 20% of cases of small cell lung cancer and are not associated with non-small cell lung cancers like lung adenocarcinoma.
questions.hint: This patient has a lung adenocarcinoma, which typically manifests as a glandular tumor in the lung periphery with papillary components and mucin. Activating mutations convert proto-oncogenes into oncogenes.

questions.text: A previously healthy 41-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of a 1-month history of painless, intermittent bleeding on defecation, which he discovered while wiping. His younger sister was recently diagnosed with endometrial cancer, and his mother was diagnosed with gastric cancer at 58 years of age. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. Colonoscopy shows a tumor in the ascending colon. Histopathologic examination of the tumor shows a mucinous, poorly-differentiated adenocarcinoma. A mutation of which of the following genes is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Germline mutations in the MLH1 gene result in defective DNA mismatch repair, the underlying cause of Lynch syndrome, which is the most common hereditary form of colorectal cancer. Patients with Lynch syndrome most often have right-sided colon cancers that are diagnosed at a relatively young age (< 50 years old). It is also associated with gastric and endometrial cancer (as seen in this patient's family), as well as ovarian cancer and urothelial cancer. Screening colonoscopy may show a limited number of polyps (usually < 10) or poorly-differentiated tumor growth, as seen in this patient. Other DNA mismatch repair genes include MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2.

Patients with Lynch syndrome should undergo aggressive screening, which includes annual colonoscopy, pelvic examination for women, and upper endoscopy starting at an early age.
Image Description:

Top: Chromosomal instability pathway (adenoma-carcinoma sequence)
- Loss of the tumor suppressor gene, APC, results in hyperproliferative epithelium due to a loss of cellular adhesion and increased cellular proliferation. A mutation in KRAS results in unregulated cellular signaling and cellular proliferation, leading to the formation of an adenoma. Loss of the tumor suppressor genes TP53 and DCC results in the malignant transformation of an adenoma to carcinoma. The chromosomal instability pathway is responsible for carcinomas in FAP (loss of APC) as well as in most cases of sporadic colorectal carcinoma.

Bottom: Microsatellite instability pathway
- Acquired or inherited mutations in the mismatch repair genes (esp. MLH1 and MSH2) result in abnormal proliferation and the formation of adenoma and carcinoma. The microsatellite instability pathway is responsible for carcinomas in Lynch syndrome (HNPCC) and a few cases of sporadic colorectal carcinoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Mutation of the TP53 gene, which encodes p53, is the underlying defect that causes Li-Fraumeni syndrome. Affected patients typically develop sarcomas, breast carcinoma, leukemia, and/or adrenocortical carcinoma. Mutation of the TP53 gene is not involved in the pathogenesis of Lynch syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Mutation of the DCC gene is responsible for the development of colon cancer. However, it is not linked to endometrial cancer or gastric cancer, which more commonly develop in patients with Lynch syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Mutation of the KRAS gene is linked to the development of colon, lung, and pancreatic cancer, not to endometrial cancer or gastric cancer, which more commonly develop in patients with Lynch syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Mutation of the APC gene causes familial adenomatous polyposis. Affected patients have hundreds of colonic polyps that develop in childhood. These can develop into colorectal cancer, often at an early age. However, FAP does not predispose to endometrial cancer or gastric cancer, which is more commonly seen in patients with Lynch syndrome.
questions.hint: This patient's family fulfills the 3-2-1 rule of Lynch syndrome: cancer in 3 affected family members, within 2 generations, and in 1 relative under 50 years of age.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman comes to the physician for a scheduled colposcopy. Two weeks ago, she had a routine Pap smear that showed atypical squamous cells. Colposcopy shows an area of white discoloration of the cervix with application of acetic acid solution. Biopsy of this area shows carcinoma-in-situ. Activation of which of the following best explains the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Phosphoprotein p24, which is a component of the HIV virus, is not related to HPV infection or the pathogenesis of cervical dysplasia as seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Mutations of the JAK-2 gene are seen in polycythemia vera, essential thrombocythemia, and other chronic myeloproliferative disorders. Although these mutations cause deregulation of cell growth and division, they are not associated with the cervical dysplasia seen in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

E2F transcription factors that promote G1 to the S phase transition are normally inhibited by the retinoblastoma protein (pRb). High-risk types of HPV induce production of the oncoprotein E7, which binds and inactivates pRb, thereby increasing G1 to S phase transition and cell proliferation. High-risk HPV also induces the production of the oncoprotein E6, which binds and inactivates the tumor suppressor protein p53.

D) INCORRECT:

The p53 protein is a key tumor suppressor. Therefore, activation of the p53 protein would inhibit rather than promote tumor growth. Oncogenic HPV DNA induces the expression of the E6 protein, which binds and inactivates p53.

E) INCORRECT:

Cyclin-dependent kinases (CDK) are responsible for progression of the cell cycle. Therefore, activation of CDK inhibitors would arrest the cell cycle and prevent rather than promote tumor growth. Oncogenic HPV DNA induces the expression of E7 protein, which binds and inactivates the CDK inhibitors p21 and p27.
questions.hint: High-risk human papillomavirus subtypes, e.g., HPV 16 and HPV 18, are responsible for the majority of cervical cancers. These pathogens facilitate the transcription of proteins that alter tumor suppression upon successful infection of cervical cells.

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman with stage IV lung cancer comes to the physician because of progressively worsening weakness over the past 3 months. She has had a 10.5-kg (23-lb) weight loss during this period. Her BMI is 16 kg/m2. She appears thin and has bilateral temporal wasting. Which of the following is the most likely primary mechanism underlying this woman's temporal muscle atrophy?

choices.text: Cytokine-mediated decrease in basal metabolic rate

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cells digest endocytosed proteins using lysosomal hydrolases. This process protects cells from foreign proteins and is a key step in MHC class II antigen presentation. However, this is not the underlying mechanism of cancer-related skeletal muscle atrophy.

B) INCORRECT:

Cytochrome c-mediated activation of proteases (caspases) leads to cell apoptosis via the intrinsic pathway of programmed cell death. Apoptosis is associated with tissue atrophy in the setting of cancer cachexia. However, it is not the primary mechanism of cancer-related skeletal muscle atrophy.

C) INCORRECT:

Cachexia due to malignancy is associated with the release of lipid-mobilizing factors from tumor cells. These factors induce hormone-sensitive lipase to degrade triglycerides, which causes adipose tissue necrosis and atrophy but not cancer-related skeletal muscle atrophy.

D) INCORRECT:

Cytokine-mediated effects on the basal metabolic rate are a key feature of the mechanism of tumor-induced cachexia. However, cachectic agents such as TNF-α, IL-1, and IL-6 increase, rather than decrease, the basal metabolic rate. Decreasing the basal metabolic rate, or resting energy expenditure, would lead to weight gain rather than cancer-related muscle atrophy, which is seen here.

E) CORRECT:

Muscle wasting in the setting of cancer cachexia is associated with the increased release of proinflammatory cytokines such as IL-1, IL-6, and TNF-α from cancer cells. These cytokines activate NF-κB, which stimulates the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway. Ubiquitinated proteins (e.g., myosin chains in skeletal muscle cells) undergo proteasomal degradation, leading to increased muscle catabolism. TNF-α in particular is known to stimulate muscle catabolism via the alteration of hormone levels that regulate muscle growth (i.e., IGF-1, GH). Furthermore, TNF-α-mediated suppression of appetite in the hypothalamus, as well as peripheral activation of lipases, leads to the reduction of body fat. Cachexia occurs not only in the setting of cancer but also in conditions such as AIDS, COPD, heart failure, or end-stage renal disease.
questions.hint: This patient has bilateral loss of temporalis muscle mass (bilateral temporal wasting) as a result of her advanced cancer. Malignant tumor cells release agents that promote cachexia via the breakdown of structural components of skeletal muscle cells.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes to the physician because of right-sided back pain, red urine, and weight loss for the last 4 months. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a large right-sided renal mass. Biopsy of the mass shows polygonal clear cells filled with lipids. Which of the following features is necessary to determine the tumor grade in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Size of malignant proliferation is considered for tumor staging. The larger the tumor, the higher the probability of metastases. Therefore, size correlates with a more advanced tumor stage. Tumor grading evaluates morphologic characteristics of tumors and is not based on tumor size.

B) INCORRECT:

The involvement of surrounding structures is determined in tumor staging, not tumor grading, which assesses the morphologic characteristics of tumor cells.

C) CORRECT:

Tumor grading determines the degree of cellular differentiation based on histological findings. Components of tumor grading systems include mitotic count, the degree of nuclear pleomorphism, and cellular organization (tubular/glandular structures). Well-differentiated tumors are classified as low-grade, whereas poorly-differentiated (or anaplastic) tumors are classified as high-grade.

D) INCORRECT:

The location of metastasis is relevant for tumor staging. Grading evaluates morphologic characteristics of tumors, not how widespread they are.

E) INCORRECT:

Involvement of regional lymph nodes is screened for tumor staging. Grading evaluates morphologic characteristics of tumors, not the involvement of distal structures.
questions.hint: Tumor grading systems determine the degree of anaplasia in neoplastic cells.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the ability of breast cancer cells to metastasize. Neoplastic cells obtained from 30 patients with stage IV ductal carcinoma of the breast are tagged with a fluorescent antibody. The cells are then inserted into a medium resembling normal human tissue. After 2 weeks, all samples show in vitro hematogenous invasion and migration away from the original site of insertion. Which of the following properties is most likely responsible for the ability of these neoplastic cells to metastasize?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Loss of cellular polarity is a hallmark of dysplastic tissue that enables asymmetric cell division, inactivates tumor suppressor proteins, and reduces pro-apoptotic signaling. The consequences of disordered cellular polarity permit tumor survival but it is not thought to be a crucial aspect of metastasis.

B) INCORRECT:

E-cadherin plays an important role in cellular adhesion and acts to oppose the metastatic process. Tumors with extensive metastatic potential would, therefore, be expected to demonstrate downregulated or inactivated E-cadherin.

C) INCORRECT:

Telomerase activity is upregulated in many neoplasms. The activity of this enzyme is part of the cellular machinery that supports immortality in tumor cell lineages. However, it does not play a role in promoting or facilitating metastasis.

D) INCORRECT:

ERBB2 overexpression is implicated in the pathogenesis of some breast cancers and results in uncontrolled cellular proliferation with suppressed apoptosis. ERBB2-positive tumors are more likely to become metastatic but the ERBB2 protein itself is not involved in the process of metastasis.

E) INCORRECT:

A high N:C ratio is a feature of neoplastic cell pleomorphism and is associated with poorly differentiated tumors and an increased likelihood of metastasis. Despite the possible prognostic value of the N:C ratio, it is not part of the metastatic mechanism.

F) INCORRECT:

Fibrous tissue capsules are a common feature of benign tumors such as adenomas or fibromas. Malignant tumors, especially those that have metastasized, would not be expected to have a capsule as this would impede local tissue invasion and distant metastasis.

G) CORRECT:

Overproduction of proteases such as collagenase and matrix metalloproteinases are essential to facilitating cancer metastasis. These enzymes cleave components of the basement membrane and interstitium, such as collagen IV. As a result, tumor cells are exposed to growth factors that promote angiogenesis and chemotaxis.
questions.hint: Not all cancers are capable of metastasis. Invasive neoplastic lesions possess specific properties that enable them to invade cell basement membranes and propagate through adjacent tissues and structures.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of multiple episodes of small amounts of blood in his stools. Examination shows pale conjunctivae. His hemoglobin concentration is 8.3 g/dL and mean corpuscular volume is 72μm3. Colonoscopy shows a 2.3-cm polypoid mass in the ascending colon. A photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen of the lesion is shown. Which of the following processes is most likely to be involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Abnormal transfer of phosphate to cellular proteins

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

COX-2 overexpression (not underexpression) is implicated in the pathogenesis of some colorectal pre-neoplastic and neoplastic growths. This is thought to be one of the major mechanisms by which aspirin may reduce the risk of colon cancer in adults.

B) INCORRECT:

Activating mutations in the proto-oncogene c-KIT permit abnormal cellular proliferation and survival. Gastrointestinal stromal tumors, germ cell tumors (e.g. seminomas), and melanomas are a few examples of cancers associated with c-KIT mutations. Precancerous polyps and colorectal carcinomas, however, are not associated with increased activity of c-KIT.

C) CORRECT:

Impaired degradation of β-catenin is implicated in the pathogenesis of precancerous polyps such as villous adenomas, which have the highest malignant potential of all types of colonic polyps. Prior to the development of true neoplastic growth, colonic epithelial cells undergo a stereotyped molecular transition from healthy to dysplastic (adenoma-carcinoma sequence). The first step is the loss of the tumor suppressor gene APC. Consequently, β-catenin accumulates and leads to inappropriate cellular proliferation.

D) INCORRECT:

Abnormal transfer of phosphate to cellular proteins occurs in neoplasms with increased kinase activity. Several kinase mutations have been implicated in cancer pathogenesis. Notable examples include BCR-ABL in chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) and acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL) and JAK2 in myeloproliferative neoplasms, not, however, precancerous polyps or colorectal carcinomas.
questions.hint: The photomicrograph shows dysplastic, enlarged glands with finger-like projections, which are features of a villous adenoma.

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman comes to the physician 2 weeks after noticing a lump in her left breast. Examination of the left breast shows a firm, nontender mass close to the nipple. Mammography shows an irregular calcified mass. A core needle biopsy shows invasive ductal carcinoma. Genetic analysis of this patient's cancer cells is most likely to show overexpression of which of the following genes?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The ERBB2 gene encodes for a growth factor receptor with intracellular tyrosine kinase activity and is overexpressed in about 20% of breast cancers. ERBB2 overexpression is typically associated with a more aggressive clinical course and worse prognosis, although the ERBB2 receptor can be directly targeted by trastuzumab. This patient's core needle specimen should also undergo immunohistochemical staining for estrogen and progesterone receptor status (positive in 70% of cases) to further delineate tumor grade and guide treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Mutations of PTEN, a tumor suppressor gene, are associated with breast, prostate, and endometrial cancer. However, cancer develops due to a loss of function of the encoded protein, not an overexpression of PTEN.

C) INCORRECT:

KRAS is a proto-oncogene that is involved in cellular growth regulation. Mutations in KRAS are typically found in colon, lung, and pancreatic cancers, but they are not associated with breast cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Mutations of TP53, a tumor suppressor gene, lead to uncontrolled cell proliferation and are thus associated with many types of cancer (e.g., sarcomas, breast cancer, leukemias). However, cancer develops due to a loss of function of the encoded p53 protein, not an overexpression of TP53.

E) INCORRECT:

BCR-ABL is a fusion gene resulting from a reciprocal translocation between chromosome 9 and chromosome 22 (t(9;22)), also known as the Philadelphia chromosome). It encodes for a nonreceptor tyrosine kinase that, as opposed to other tyrosine kinases, is continuously activated, leading to uncontrolled cell proliferation. A Philadelphia translocation is most commonly found in chronic myeloid leukemia; it is not associated with breast cancer.

F) INCORRECT:

BRCA-2 is a tumor suppressor gene involved in DNA repair processes. Autosomal dominant inherited mutations of this gene strongly predispose to development of several cancers, especially breast cancer and ovarian cancer. However, this increased risk is due to a loss of function of the encoded DNA repair protein, not an overexpression of BRCA-2.
questions.hint: This gene encodes an epidermal growth factor receptor involved in regulating cell growth and differentiation.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of a skin lesion on his right arm. The lesion first appeared 3 months ago and has since been slowly enlarging. Physical examination shows a 1.5-centimeter, faintly erythematous, raised lesion with irregular borders on the dorsum of the right forearm. A biopsy specimen is obtained. If present, which of the following histopathological features would be most consistent with carcinoma in situ?

choices.text: Pleomorphism of cells in the stratum corneum
Irreversible nuclear changes in the stratum basale
Full-thickness basal to apical cell polarity
Increased nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio in the stratum spinosum
High mitotic activity in the stratum granulosum

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pleomorphism of cells in the stratum corneum is a feature of dysplasia, a still reversible process that can lead to carcinoma in situ. However, it is not only seen in cases that develop into carcinoma in situ.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a cervical biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

1. Normal squamous epithelium (N; green overlay): normal nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio, intact cell polarity (epithelial cells have distinct lateral, apical, and basal membrane domains)

2. Mild dysplasia (1; yellow overlay): mild pleomorphism (loss of uniformity in cell size and shape), mild chromatin abnormalities (hyperchromatic), koilocytes (cells with perinuclear halos), dysplasia confined to the basal third of the epithelium

3. Moderate dysplasia (2; blue overlay): loss of cell polarity, moderate nuclear pleomorphism, moderate nuclear chromatin abnormalities, increased normal and abnormal mitosis, dysplasia confined to the basal two-thirds of the epithelium

4. Severe dysplasia (3; red overlay): irreversible high-grade dysplasia, irregular epithelial stratification, involves the entire thickness of the epithelium, clear demarcated basement membrane (no invasion)

Koilocytes in dysplastic cervical epithelium indicate an underlying persistent HPV infection as the cause of dysplasia.

B) CORRECT:

Formation of neoplasia starts with low-grade dysplasia, a reversible disordered growth of epithelium characterized by abnormally frequent mitotic figures, loss of cell orientation and uniformity, and nuclear changes. Carcinoma in situ is usually an irreversible severe (i.e., high-grade) dysplasia involving the entire thickness of the epithelium without basement membrane penetration.

C) INCORRECT:

A basal to apical cell polarity is a physiological feature of epithelial cells or epithelial cell layers, which line the body's surfaces and separate internal cavities from the outside environment. Loss of this polarity, however, is a sign of dysplasia, which may eventually lead to carcinoma in situ.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio in the stratum spinosum is a feature of dysplasia, a still reversible process that can lead to carcinoma in situ. However, it is not only seen in cases that develop into carcinoma in situ.

E) INCORRECT:

High mitotic activity in the stratum granulosum would be a feature of dysplasia, a still reversible process that can lead to carcinoma in situ. However, it is not only seen in cases that develop into carcinoma in situ.
questions.hint: Neoplasia progresses along a predictable course from normal cellular morphology to the reversible changes of dysplasia and then to carcinoma in situ.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man receives chemotherapy for advanced hepatocellular carcinoma. Despite appropriate therapy, he dies 4 months later. Histopathological examination of the cancer cells shows the presence of a transmembrane efflux pump protein that is known to cause decreased intracellular concentrations of chemotherapeutic drugs. Which of the following best describes this membrane protein?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

P-glycoprotein, also called MDR1, is an ATP-binding transporter that pumps drugs out of the cell thereby causing resistance to a variety of drugs. This mechanism renders cells resistant to a number of chemotherapeutics, including tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., imatinib), topoisomerase inhibitors (e.g., doxorubicin), and microtubule inhibitors (e.g., vincristine).

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased expression of cadherins allows solid tumor cells to penetrate the basement membrane and migrate to other tissues, making it a critical step in tumor invasion and metastasis. However, cadherin proteins do not play a role in the influx, efflux, or metabolism of chemotherapeutics.

C) INCORRECT:

Chemotherapeutics targeting receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) are effective in the treatment of some malignancies (e.g., adenocarcinoma of the lung and chronic myelogenous leukemia), and mutations in RTKs can induce resistance to these drugs. However, tyrosine receptors do not facilitate the ATP-dependent efflux of chemotherapeutics from cancer cells.

D) INCORRECT:

G protein-coupled receptors are transmembrane receptors that play a critical role in cell activation and inhibition. However, they do not play a role in the influx, efflux, or metabolism of chemotherapeutics.

E) INCORRECT:

Channel proteins play a critical role in both signal transduction and inhibition. Some bacteria develop resistance to antibiotics through mutations affecting the expression of porins. However, channel proteins do not play a role in the ATP-dependent influx, efflux, or metabolism of chemotherapeutics.
questions.hint: The membrane protein that most likely caused drug resistance in this patient is also called multidrug resistance protein 1 (MDR1).

questions.text: A 57-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-week history of constipation, episodic bloody stools, progressive fatigue, and a 5-kg (10.2-lb) weight loss. Digital rectal examination shows a hard, 1.5-cm rectal mass. A biopsy confirms the diagnosis of colorectal carcinoma. The patient begins treatment with a combination chemotherapy regimen that includes a drug that is also used in the treatment of wet age-related macular degeneration. This drug most likely acts by inhibiting which of the following substances?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fibroblast growth factor and receptor (FGF/FGFR) are tyrosine kinase signaling pathway molecules that regulate numerous processes, including embryogenesis, angiogenesis, tissue homeostasis, and wound repair. However, FGF inhibitors (e.g., lenvatinib) are not used in the treatment of advanced cancers (e.g., colorectal cancer) or in the management of age-related macular degeneration (AMD).

B) INCORRECT:

Chemotherapeutic drugs such as cetuximab, gefitinib, and erlotinib bind and block epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR), which inhibits cell growth in tumors that overexpress EGFR. As such, they are readily prescribed to patients with non-small cell lung cancer and colorectal cancer. However, EGFRs do not play a role in the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration and are therefore not targeted in its management.

C) INCORRECT:

Metalloproteinase is an enzyme that breaks down components of the extracellular matrix that are also involved in wound healing and scar formation. The role of tissue inhibitors of metalloproteinases (TIMPs) in advanced (or metastatic) cancers is currently being investigated. Despite a few promising studies, TIMPs are not currently being used in the treatment of advanced cancers like colorectal cancer, nor are they used in the management of age-related macular degeneration.

D) INCORRECT:

Interferon-alpha (IFN-α) is an antiviral and immunomodulatory glycoprotein obtained from human leukocytes. As a chemotherapeutic agent, IFN-α has been shown to decrease cellular proliferation and inhibit angiogenesis. IFNs have a dual role in promoting and inhibiting proliferation; studies have found them to function as both a tumor promoter and tumor suppressor in colorectal cancer (CRC). As such, giving a patient with CRC IFN-α might slow down cancer progression. However, IFN-α is not used in the management of age-related macular degeneration.

E) INCORRECT:

Platelet factor 4 (PF4) is produced by platelets and plays a role in both inflammation and wound healing as well as inhibition of angiogenesis. It is mainly used in treatment of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia, not advanced cancers (such as colorectal cancer) or age-related macular degeneration.

F) CORRECT:

Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) is a signaling molecule that stimulates de novo formation of blood vessels. Bevacizumab, a humanized monoclonal antibody, is one of the most prescribed anti-VEGF medications. It is usually given in combination with cisplatin and paclitaxel, and is used as first-line or second-line therapy in many advanced (or metastatic) cancers, including colorectal cancer, advanced non-small cell lung cancer, metastatic renal cell carcinoma, and metastatic breast cancer. The overexpression of VEGF is the most likely cause of choroidal neovascularization, the leading cause of blindness in age-related macular degeneration.
questions.hint: Bevacizumab is used in the treatment of neovascular age-related macular degeneration and many advanced malignancies.

questions.text: A previously healthy 48-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of weight loss and yellowing of the skin. He works as a farmer and cultivates soybean and corn. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and tender hepatomegaly. Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows a 5-cm nodular lesion in the right lobe of the liver. Further evaluation of the lesion confirms hepatocellular carcinoma. The activity of which of the following enzymes most likely contributed to the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Peroxisomal catalases are enzymes that prevent the formation of free radicals by converting peroxide to water and oxygen. Free radicals are involved in both the initiation and promotion of multistage carcinogenesis (e.g., benzo(a)pyrene in lung cancer). A decrease in peroxisomal catalase activity would therefore promote free radical formation and subsequent activation of procarcinogens. However, normal peroxisomal catalase activity would be a limiting factor in the pathogenesis of this patient's disease rather than a contributing factor.

B) INCORRECT:

Lysosomal proteases belong to the aspartic, cysteine, and serine proteinase families of ubiquitously expressed hydrolytic enzymes, which play a role in tumor metastases and invasion. While cysteine proteases (cathepsin B) are involved in the development of hepatocellular carcinoma, serine proteases (cathepsin A and G) are not. Serine proteases are therefore unlikely to have contributed to the pathogenesis of this patient's disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Cytosolic cysteine proteases (or caspases) are involved in apoptosis. Cysteine-aspartic protease activity would be a limiting factor in the pathogenesis of this patient's disease rather than a contributing factor. Furthermore, cytosolic cysteine protease is not involved in the activation of aflatoxin or the development of hepatocellular carcinoma.

D) CORRECT:

The primary function of the microsomal cytochrome P450 monooxygenase system is the metabolization of xenobiotics (e.g., drugs, toxins) and hydrophobic endogenous compounds (e.g., steroids) to allow for their excretion. These same enzymes can also convert procarcinogens to carcinogens, which can induce DNA mutations, thereby promoting carcinogenesis. In this patient, activation of the procarcinogen aflatoxin B1 by microsomal monooxygenases most likely led to the development of HCC. A metabolite of aflatoxin B1 interferes with proper DNA transcription of the TP53 gene through an inactivating mutation, resulting in a G:C → T:A transversion. This mutation is found in up to 60% of individuals with HCC in areas with high levels of exposure to aflatoxin B1.

E) INCORRECT:

Nuclear glycosylases are involved in base excision repair, a type of DNA repair. This process would limit carcinogenesis rather than contribute to it. Furthermore, nuclear glycosylases are not involved in the activation of aflatoxin and the development of hepatocellular carcinoma.
questions.hint: Aspergillus often grows on agricultural products such as peanuts, corn, and soybean. Chronic exposure to aflatoxin, which is produced by some species of Aspergillus, is a risk factor for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

questions.text: A 41-year-old man with HIV comes to the physician because of rectal bleeding and itching for 2 weeks. During this period, he has also had pain with defecation. Four months ago, he was diagnosed with anogenital warts that were treated with cryotherapy. Over the past year, he has been sexually active with 3 male partners. He uses condoms inconsistently. Current medications are zidovudine, emtricitabine, and efavirenz. Digital rectal examination and anoscopy show an exophytic mass on the anal margin that is protruding into the anal canal. The mass is tender to palpation and bleeds easily on contact. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 7,600/mm3 and a CD4+ T-lymphocyte count of 410/mm3. A biopsy specimen of the lesion shows a well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. Which of the following cellular processes was most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's malignancy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Activation of the c-myc proto-oncogene is associated with infection with Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV), an oncogenic virus that can cause endemic Burkitt lymphoma. c-myc codes for a transcription factor that, when overexpressed, leads to unregulated cell proliferation and differentiation. In most cases of Burkitt lymphoma, the overactivation of c-myc is due to the translocation t(8;14). However, the c-myc gene is not involved in the pathogenesis of malignancy caused by infection with HPV-16 and HPV-18.

B) INCORRECT:

Inactivation of the von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) tumor suppressor gene due to a loss-of-function mutation can lead to von Hippel-Lindau disease. VHL is a protein involved in the degradation of hypoxia-inducible factor 1a (HIF-1). Deletion of VHL results in increased activity of HIF-1, which induces the transcription of target genes involved in the response to hypoxia (e.g., EPO and VEGF). VHL disease causes hemangioblastomas, bilateral renal cell carcinoma, and pheochromocytoma; however, it is not associated with anal squamous cell carcinoma. Moreover, the VHL gene is not involved in the pathogenesis of malignancy caused by infection with HPV-16 and HPV-18.

C) INCORRECT:

Activation of the TAX proto-oncogene is associated with infection with human T-lymphotropic virus type I (HTLV-I), an oncogenic virus that can cause adult T-cell leukemia (ATL). Once a CD4+ T-cell is infected by HTLV-I, TAX induces overexpression of stimulatory host transcription factors (e.g., NF-kB), which leads to uncontrolled T-cell proliferation. However, the TAX gene is not involved in the pathogenesis of malignancy caused by infection with HPV-16 and HPV-18.

D) INCORRECT:

Inactivation of Wilms tumor 1 (WT1) gene, a tumor suppressor gene that encodes for a transcription factor responsible for urogenital development, is caused by a loss-of-function mutation and can lead to malignancy (e.g., nephroblastoma) or genomic syndromes (e.g., Denys-Drash syndrome, WAGR syndrome). However, it is not associated with anal squamous cell carcinoma. Moreover, the WT1 gene is not involved in the pathogenesis of malignancy caused by infection with HPV-16 and HPV-18.

E) INCORRECT:

Activation of the KRAS gene, a proto-oncogene that encodes for a GTPase involved in the regulation of cell growth, is caused by a point mutation and has been implicated in the development of several cancers, including pancreatic adenocarcinoma, non-small cell lung cancer, and colorectal cancer. However, it is not associated with anal squamous cell carcinoma. Moreover, the KRAS gene is not involved in the pathogenesis of malignancy caused by infection with HPV-16 and HPV-18.

F) CORRECT:

Inactivation of the tumor suppressor proteins p53 and retinoblastoma protein (pRb) is implicated in the pathogenesis of malignancy caused by infection with the oncogenic viruses HPV-16 and HPV-18. HPV-16 produces oncoprotein E6, which inhibits p53. Oncoprotein E7 is produced by HPV-18 and inhibits pRb. Inactivation of these proteins leads to the continued growth and proliferation of damaged cells. General risk factors for the development of anal cancer include immunocompromised status (e.g., HIV), receptive anal intercourse, and infection with HPV (e.g., anogenital warts). HPV-16 and HPV-18 are also involved in the development of cervical, oral, and oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinomas.

Kaposi sarcoma, a malignancy strongly associated with HIV, is also caused by an oncogenic virus, HHV-8. This herpesvirus infects human endothelial cells and transforms them into neoplastic spindle cells via various oncogenic products that affect cell cycle regulation and apoptosis.
questions.hint: Infection with oncogenic human papillomavirus (HPV) strains likely played a role in the development of this patient's anal cancer.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the physician because of worsening lower back pain for 6 weeks. He reports that the pain is most intense with movement and that it sometimes occurs at night. Over the past 3 months, he has noticed a weakened urinary stream. He has not seen any blood in his urine. His only daily medication is ibuprofen, which does not provide adequate pain relief. Examination shows no spinal deformities. Palpation of the lumbar spinal process elicits localized tenderness. Muscle strength is normal. Sensation is intact bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s back pain?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Subacute progressive lumbar back pain and a weakened urinary stream in a patient > 50 years of age should raise suspicion for advanced-stage prostate cancer with bony metastasis. Prostate cancer is frequently associated with skeletal metastases, with the spine being the most common location. Accordingly, some patients present with lower back pain as the initial manifestation. Red flags for metastatic bone disease include a history of cancer, advanced age, unexplained weight loss, and bone pain that does not improve after one month. Besides pain, which commonly occurs at night and exacerbates with movement, patients with metastatic bone disease from prostate cancer can present with pathologic fractures, hypocalcemia (due to osteoblastic metastasis), and neurological deficits (due to spinal cord compression).

B) INCORRECT:

Lower back pain is a common manifestation of lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS), a condition that mostly affects individuals > 60 years of age. LSS typically causes bilateral radiating pain to the buttocks and/or legs that is exacerbated by activities involving lumbar extension (e.g., standing, walking downhill) and relieved by lumbar flexion (e.g., sitting or lying down when sleeping). Furthermore, he does not have typical symptoms of LSS, such as cramping, numbness, weakness, or tingling in the legs. While LSS can rarely lead to urinary retention symptoms secondary to cauda equina syndrome, this patient's normal sensorimotor function makes such a diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

Pain due to lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS) is typically dependent on postural changes. Symptoms typically improve when sitting or leaning forward (shopping-cart sign), as lumbar flexion widens the central spinal canal and relieves nerve root compression. In contrast, symptoms typically worsen with positions involving lumbar extension (e.g., walking, prolonged standing). This phenomenon is referred to as neuropathic claudication and is a hallmark of LSS.

C) INCORRECT:

Individuals with osteoporosis have an increased susceptibility to pathological vertebral compression fractures. These fractures may manifest with lower back pain and point tenderness. However, a more acute presentation would be expected in a fracture. Moreover, osteoporosis most commonly affects postmenopausal women, individuals > 70 years of age, and individuals with risk factors such as long-term steroid therapy. While vertebral compression fractures can rarely lead to urinary retention symptoms secondary to cauda equina syndrome, this patient's normal sensorimotor function makes such a diagnosis unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Subacute lower back pain worsened by palpation is a typical manifestation of a spinal epidural abscess (SEA). However, SEA is commonly associated with further symptoms, such as fever, malaise, and, eventually, neurologic deficits (secondary to spinal cord compression). Moreover, this patient has no risk factors for this condition (e.g., IV drug use, recent invasive spinal procedures, immunosuppression). While SEA can rarely lead to urinary retention symptoms secondary to cauda equina syndrome, this patient's normal sensorimotor function makes such a diagnosis unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Lumbar disk herniation can manifest with severe lower back pain. However, disk herniation typically manifests with an acute stabbing pain that radiates to the legs and is associated with neurological deficits, such as paresthesia, loss of deep tendon reflexes, and muscle weakness. Moreover, disk herniation is usually triggered by physical exertion (e.g., bending, heavy lifting), which this patient has not reported. While a large posteromedial disk herniation can lead to urinary retention symptoms secondary to cauda equina syndrome, this patient's normal sensorimotor function makes such a diagnosis unlikely.

F) INCORRECT:

Lumbar muscle strain is the most common cause of lower back pain. Muscle strain can manifest with lower back pain that is most intense with movement, reproducible on palpation, and not associated with sensory or motor dysfunction. Nocturnal pain and a weakened urinary stream, however, are not associated with lumbar strain. Lack of improvement after 6 weeks of therapy with NSAIDs should further raise suspicion for a nonmuscular cause of the pain. Moreover, lumbar muscle strain is usually triggered by physical exertion (e.g., heavy lifting), which this patient has not reported.
questions.hint: The most important risk factor for this patient's underlying disease is advanced age (> 50 years).

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive shortness of breath and a worsening cough for the past month. He also reports occasional bloody sputum. He has lost about 7 kg (15.4 lb) of weight over the past 6 months despite having no change in appetite. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 15 years but stopped smoking at the age of 55. Physical examination shows reduced breath sounds throughout both lungs. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Squamous cell lung carcinoma can manifest with progressive dyspnea, cough, hemoptysis, and weight loss, all of which are seen in this patient. Moreover, this type of primary lung cancer is strongly associated with smoking. However, a chest x-ray would typically show a hilar mass and cavitation rather than the multiple, bilateral lesions seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Small cell lung cancer (SCLC) can manifest with progressive dyspnea, cough, hemoptysis, and weight loss, all of which are seen in this patient. Moreover, this type of primary lung cancer is strongly associated with smoking. However, a chest x-ray would typically show a single central nodule rather than the multiple, bilateral lesions seen here. In addition, SCLC is commonly accompanied by paraneoplastic syndromes (e.g., syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion, Cushing syndrome), which this patient does not have.

C) INCORRECT:

Lung adenocarcinoma, which is the most common type of primary lung cancer, can manifest with progressive dyspnea, cough, hemoptysis, and weight loss, all of which are seen in this patient. However, a chest x-ray would typically show a single peripheral nodule rather than the multiple, bilateral lesions seen here.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with bronchogenic carcinoma

A solitary nodule (red overlay) with an irregular margin is visible in the periphery of the upper left lung. An additional soft-tissue opacity peripheral to the nodule along the ribs may represent adjacent pleural thickening (green overlay).

The differential diagnosis for a solitary pulmonary nodule includes neoplastic (malignant and benign), inflammatory, and congenital conditions.

D) CORRECT:

Round nodules of varying sizes scattered throughout the lungs (“cannonball lesions”) suggest pulmonary metastases. Moreover, this patient reports that systemic symptoms (i.e., weight loss) preceded the onset of pulmonary symptoms (dyspnea, cough, hemoptysis) by several months, which should raise suspicion for a primary extrathoracic malignancy. Lung metastases occur in up to 50% of cancer patients, with breast, colorectal, and renal carcinomas among the most common primary tumors in adults. An extensive diagnostic workup (e.g., imaging, biopsy with histology and immunohistochemistry) should be initiated to identify this patient's primary malignancy.
Image Description:

CT chest (axial plane; lung window) of a patient with lung metastases from colon carcinoma

Multiple small, circumscribed nodules of varying sizes (examples indicated by green overlays) can be seen in both lungs. A few nodules (examples indicated by red overlays) contain small foci of air, which may represent small bronchioles or sites of early cavitation.

E) INCORRECT:

Pleural mesothelioma can manifest with progressive dyspnea, cough, and weight loss, all of which are seen in this patient. However, this type of malignancy almost exclusively occurs due to inhalational asbestos exposure, which this patient has not reported. Moreover, a chest x-ray would typically show pleural plaques and/or calcifications and unilateral pleural effusion rather than the multiple pulmonary lesions seen here.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with mesothelioma

A rounded opacity (green overlay) superior to the right hilum has a circumscribed inferior margin and an ill-defined superior margin (incomplete border sign). Similar smaller partially circumscribed opacities (examples indicated by red overlay) project over several ribs in the mid-right hemithorax. The presence of an incomplete border sign helps distinguish extrapulmonary (pleural or chest wall) masses from lung masses on a chest radiograph. An Implantable cardiac defibrillator (ICD)-pacemaker is also seen.
questions.hint: The patient's chest x-ray shows numerous round, well-circumscribed pulmonary lesions.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man reports a 4-month history of anorexia, unintentional substantial weight loss, and lethargy. He has also noted several scattered purple bumps on his skin. Physical examination reveals normal vital signs, a slightly cachectic appearance, and several purple-brown, variably sized, tender subcutaneous nodules (figure). The remainder of the examination is normal.
Which one of the following diagnoses is the most likely cause of this patient’s skin lesions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gardner syndrome, a genetic disorder associated with colorectal polyposis, typically manifests in younger patients with colonic polyps and cutaneous cysts.

B) INCORRECT:

Intradermal cocaine use often presents on the skin as tissue necrosis with erosion and ulceration. The lesions are typically observed in sites of injection.

C) INCORRECT:

The lesions of miliary tuberculosis are tiny, monomorphic, pinpoint papules, not subcutaneous nodules.

D) CORRECT:

Cutaneous metastases of internal malignancy should be suspected when an older patient presents with cachexia and numerous subcutaneous nodules. Cutaneous metastases can present variably as tender or nontender nodules, depending on anatomic location, the histology of the primary tumor, and the presence or absence of ulceration. In men, lung cancer, colon cancer, and melanoma are the most common primary tumors that metastasize to skin. In women, breast tumors are the leading cause of cutaneous metastasis.

Key learning point: Numerous scattered subcutaneous nodules in an older, cachectic patient raises concern for cutaneous metastases.

E) INCORRECT:

Lipomas are subcutaneous nodules that are generally nontender and rubbery and rarely require therapy. They are not associated with weight loss.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the office because of worsening lower back pain for 6 weeks. He reports that the pain is most intense with movement and that it sometimes occurs at night. Over the past 3 months, he has noticed a weakened urinary stream. Examination shows no spinal deformities. Palpation of the lumbar spinal process elicits localized tenderness. Muscle strength is normal. Sensation is intact bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s back pain?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Subacute progressive lumbar back pain and a weakened urinary stream in a patient > 50 years of age should raise suspicion for advanced-stage prostate cancer with bony metastasis. Prostate cancer is frequently associated with skeletal metastases, with the spine being the most common location. Accordingly, some patients present with lower back pain as the initial manifestation. Red flags for metastatic bone disease include a history of cancer, advanced age, unexplained weight loss, and bone pain that does not improve after one month. Besides pain, which commonly occurs at night and exacerbates with movement, patients with metastatic bone disease from prostate cancer can present with pathologic fractures, hypocalcemia (due to osteoblastic metastasis), and neurological deficits (due to spinal cord compression).

B) INCORRECT:

Lower back pain is a common manifestation of lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS), a condition that mostly affects individuals > 60 years of age. LSS typically causes bilateral radiating pain to the buttocks and/or legs that is exacerbated by activities involving lumbar extension (e.g., standing, walking downhill) and relieved by lumbar flexion (e.g., sitting or lying down when sleeping). Furthermore, he does not have typical symptoms of LSS, such as cramping, numbness, weakness, or tingling in the legs. While LSS can rarely lead to urinary retention symptoms secondary to cauda equina syndrome, this patient's normal sensorimotor function makes such a diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

Pain due to lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS) is typically dependent on postural changes. Symptoms typically improve when sitting or leaning forward (shopping-cart sign), as lumbar flexion widens the central spinal canal and relieves nerve root compression. In contrast, symptoms typically worsen with positions involving lumbar extension (e.g., walking, prolonged standing). This phenomenon is referred to as neuropathic claudication and is a hallmark of LSS.

C) INCORRECT:

Moreover, osteoporosis most commonly affects postmenopausal women, individuals > 70 years of age, and individuals with risk factors such as long-term steroid therapy. While vertebral compression fractures can rarely lead to urinary retention symptoms secondary to cauda equina syndrome, this patient's normal sensorimotor function makes such a diagnosis unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Lumbar disk herniation can manifest with severe lower back pain. However, disk herniation typically manifests with an acute stabbing pain that radiates to the legs and is associated with neurological deficits, such as paresthesia, loss of deep tendon reflexes, and muscle weakness. Moreover, disk herniation is usually triggered by physical exertion (e.g., bending, heavy lifting), which this patient has not reported. While a large posteromedial disk herniation can lead to urinary retention symptoms secondary to cauda equina syndrome, this patient's normal sensorimotor function makes such a diagnosis unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Lumbar muscle strain is the most common cause of lower back pain. Muscle strain can manifest with lower back pain that is most intense with movement, reproducible on palpation, and not associated with sensory or motor dysfunction. Nocturnal pain and a weakened urinary stream, however, are not associated with lumbar strain. Moreover, lumbar muscle strain is usually triggered by physical exertion (e.g., heavy lifting), which this patient has not reported.
questions.hint: The most important risk factor for this patient's underlying disease is advanced age (> 50 years).

questions.text: You are seeing a 57-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department by his wife 20 minutes after experiencing a seizure. He has had recurrent headaches and dizziness for the past 2 weeks. MRI of the brain reveals multiple, round, well-demarcated lesions in the brain parenchyma at the junction between gray and white matter. The cells comprising these brain lesions most likely originate from which one of the following organs?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although breast cancers have a tendency to metastasize to the brain, they are not the most common origin of brain metastases. Moreover, cancers of the breast rarely occur in men.

B) INCORRECT:

Thyroid cancers that spread hematogenously (i.e., follicular thyroid cancer, anaplastic thyroid cancer, and medullary thyroid cancer) predominantly metastasize to the bone and lung but rarely to the brain. Papillary thyroid cancer metastasizes predominantly through lymphatics to the regional lymph nodes; distant metastases from papillary thyroid cancer are uncommon.

C) INCORRECT:

Renal cell carcinoma most frequently metastasizes to the lungs as the tumor emboli enter the renal vein and inferior vena cava and reach the lungs via the pulmonary artery. Although kidney cancers may rarely metastasize to the brain, they are not the most common origin of brain metastases.

D) INCORRECT:

Colon cancer classically metastasizes hematogenously first to the liver, as venous blood from the colon drains into the portal vein and the hepatic sinusoids, seeding the tumor emboli within the liver parenchyma. Although colon cancers have a tendency to metastasize to the brain, they are not the most common origin of brain metastases.

E) CORRECT:

Primary cancers of the lung (particularly small cell lung cancer and adenocarcinoma of the lung) are the most common origin of brain metastases. The 2nd most common origin of brain metastases are cancers of the breast followed by melanoma and cancers of the kidney and colon. Metastatic disease accounts for approx. 50% of all brain tumors.

See “Common origins of cancer metastases” table.

Key learning point: Lung cancer is the most common primary source of brain metastases, followed by breast cancer, melanoma, kidney, and colon cancers.
Image Description:

Arrows have been color-coded according to the site of the primary tumor:

Pink: skin cancer
Blue: breast cancer
Green: lung cancer
Orange: pancreatic cancer
Red: colon cancer
Lime: ovarian cancer

The table provides examples of suffixes used to specify the affected organs according to the TNM classification.
questions.hint: The junction between the gray and white matter is the typical location for brain metastases, the most common type of intracranial tumors, which visualize as round, well-demarcated intraparenchymal lesions on MRI.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 6-week history of worsening lower back pain. He reports that the pain is most intense with movement and sometimes occurs at night. Over the past 3 months, he has also noticed a weakened urinary stream. On examination, there are no spinal deformities. Palpation of the lumbar spinal process elicits localized tenderness. Muscle strength and sensation are normal bilaterally. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of his back pain?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lumbar muscle strain is the most common cause of lower back pain. Muscle strain can manifest with lower back pain that is most intense with movement, reproducible on palpation, and not associated with sensory or motor dysfunction. Nocturnal pain and a weakened urinary stream, however, are not associated with lumbar strain. Moreover, lumbar muscle strain is usually triggered by physical exertion (e.g., heavy lifting), which this patient has not reported.

B) INCORRECT:

Individuals with osteoporosis have an increased susceptibility to pathological vertebral compression fractures. These fractures may manifest with lower back pain and point tenderness. However, a more acute presentation would be expected in a fracture. Moreover, osteoporosis most commonly affects postmenopausal women, individuals > 70 years of age, and individuals with risk factors such as long-term steroid therapy. While vertebral compression fractures can rarely lead to urinary retention symptoms secondary to cauda equina syndrome, this patient's normal sensorimotor function makes such a diagnosis unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Lumbar disk herniation can manifest with severe lower back pain. However, disk herniation typically manifests with an acute stabbing pain that radiates to the legs and is associated with neurological deficits, such as paresthesia, loss of deep tendon reflexes, and muscle weakness. Moreover, disk herniation is usually triggered by physical exertion (e.g., bending, heavy lifting), which this patient has not reported. While a large posteromedial disk herniation can lead to urinary retention symptoms secondary to cauda equina syndrome, this patient's normal sensorimotor function makes such a diagnosis unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Lower back pain is a common manifestation of lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS), a condition that mostly affects individuals > 60 years of age. LSS typically causes bilateral radiating pain to the buttocks and/or legs that is exacerbated by activities involving lumbar extension (e.g., standing, walking downhill) and relieved by lumbar flexion (e.g., sitting or lying down when sleeping). Furthermore, he does not have typical symptoms of LSS, such as cramping, numbness, weakness, or tingling in the legs. While LSS can rarely lead to urinary retention symptoms secondary to cauda equina syndrome, this patient's normal sensorimotor function makes such a diagnosis unlikely.

E) CORRECT:

Subacute progressive lumbar back pain and a weakened urinary stream in a patient > 50 years of age should raise suspicion for advanced-stage prostate cancer with bony metastasis. Prostate cancer is frequently associated with skeletal metastases, with the spine being the most common location. Accordingly, some patients present with lower back pain as the initial manifestation. Red flags for metastatic bone disease include a history of cancer, advanced age, unexplained weight loss, and bone pain that does not improve after one month. Besides pain, which commonly occurs at night and exacerbates with movement, patients with metastatic bone disease from prostate cancer can present with pathologic fractures, hypocalcemia (due to osteoblastic metastasis), and neurological deficits (due to spinal cord compression).

Key learning point: In older adults, persistent or progressive back pain—especially with nocturnal symptoms or urinary changes—should raise suspicion for malignancy, such as metastatic prostate cancer to the spine.
questions.hint: The most important risk factor for this patient's underlying disease is advanced age (> 50 years).

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant with left sided neck swelling is brought to the ED by foster parents, having been placed in foster care yesterday. Photographs provided by the infant's grandmother suggest the swelling has been present for at least a month. The infant is afebrile, feeding well, and breathing comfortably. Examination shows a soft, nontender, compressible mass in the left posterior triangle of the neck without erythema, warmth, or overlying skin changes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Branchial cleft cysts typically occur along the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle and are firm, well circumscribed, and noncompressible. Branchial cleft cysts are less likely to manifest in the posterior triangle or manifest as soft, diffuse swelling.

B) INCORRECT:

Reactive lymphadenopathy manifests with small, firm, sometimes tender nodes following infection. The absence of fever, tenderness, or preceding illness makes this diagnosis unlikely in an afebrile infant.

C) INCORRECT:

Thyroglossal duct cysts usually occur in the midline and move with swallowing or tongue protrusion. This lesion is located in the posterior triangle of the neck, making another diagnosis more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

A deep neck abscess typically manifests acutely with pain, fever, and erythema. This infant is afebrile and appears well, making an infectious process unlikely.

E) CORRECT:

Correct — Lymphangioma is a congenital lymphatic malformation commonly located in the posterior triangle of the neck. Cystic hygroma manifests as a soft, nontender, compressible swelling that may enlarge gradually. Identifying a cystic hygroma in the ED is important to assess for airway compromise or dysphagia and to arrange imaging and surgical consult for definitive management.

questions.text: A 69-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of cough with blood-tinged sputum and a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 38 years. Auscultation of the lungs shows wheezing in the right lung field. An x-ray of the chest shows an irregular lesion with a central cavity in the proximal right lung. A lung biopsy shows malignant cells that express desmoglein and stain positive for cytokeratin. Which of the following findings confers the worst prognosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

High mitotic activity is a tumor grading criteria used to designate high-grade tumors (e.g., anaplastic or malignant meningiomas) and is a measure of how fast tumor cells are growing and dividing. However, the stage of a tumor is generally more important than its grade in determining the prognosis.

B) INCORRECT:

A high nucleus to cytoplasmic ratio (N:C) is a tumor grading criteria used to evaluate for atypia and can be a predictor of malignancy. However, the stage of a tumor is generally more important than its grade in determining the prognosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Squamous cell carcinomas of the lung often show extensive central necrosis with cavitary lesions as seen on this patient's x-ray. Although tumor necrosis is associated with poor prognosis, the presence of necrosis is not thought to provide any independent prognostic information. Moreover, necrosis is not a criterion for the stage of a tumor, which generally is most significant in determining the prognosis.

D) CORRECT:

Mediastinal invasion by cancer cells classifies a tumor as T4 per TNM classification system and would confer the worst prognosis in this patient. Besides tumor size and invasiveness (T), the TNM score includes the extent of lymph node involvement (N) and the presence of distant metastases (M), both of which are typically the most important prognostic factors for survival. Staging as a measure of tumor spread is generally more significant in determining the prognosis than tumor grading.

E) INCORRECT:

Poor cellular differentiation is a tumor grading criteria used to designate high-grade tumors. However, the stage of a tumor is generally more important than its grade in determining the prognosis.
questions.hint: This patient's history, the proximal lesion on x-ray, and biopsy findings are consistent with squamous cell carcinoma of the lung. Tumor staging provides the most important prognostic value for survival.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician 1 week after noticing a lump in her right breast. Fifteen years ago, she was diagnosed with osteosarcoma of her left distal femur. Her father died of an adrenocortical carcinoma at the age of 41 years. Examination shows a 2-cm, firm, immobile mass in the lower outer quadrant of the right breast. A core needle biopsy of the mass shows adenocarcinoma. Genetic analysis in this patient is most likely to show a defect in which of the following genes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

RET proto-oncogene mutations are associated with MEN 2A and MEN 2B syndromes, and medullary thyroid carcinoma. This patient has no history of medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma or primary hyperparathyroidism, making MEN 2A and MEN 2B unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

KRAS proto-oncogene encodes a GTPase that regulates cellular growth. KRAS proto-oncogene mutations are associated with colon cancer, non-small cell lung cancers, and pancreatic cancers, but not with breast, adrenal or bone malignancies.

C) CORRECT:

Genetic analysis in this patient is most likely to show a TP53 tumor suppressor gene mutation resulting in Li-Fraumeni syndrome. TP53 regulates cell apoptosis and cell cycle arrest at the G1 phase (by activating p21) and inhibits entry in the S phase of the cell cycle. In the absence of the normal activated p53 protein, cells containing damaged DNA can proliferate, resulting in malignant transformation. Common malignancies include osteosarcomas, breast cancer, brain tumors, and adrenocortical carcinomas.

See “Overview of tumor suppressor genes” table.

D) INCORRECT:

BRCA mutations are associated with an increased risk of breast cancer and ovarian cancer, as well as colon, pancreas, stomach and prostate cancer. They are not associated with osteosarcoma and adrenocortical carcinoma.

E) INCORRECT:

MLH1 is a DNA mismatch repair gene. Mutation in this gene is associated with Lynch syndrome (HNPCC) and breast cancer. Osteosarcoma and adrenocortical carcinoma are more commonly associated with Li-Fraumeni syndrome.

F) INCORRECT:

Mutations in the PTEN gene are associated with prostate cancer and Cowden syndrome. Osteosarcoma and adrenal tumors are not usually associated.

G) INCORRECT:

Rb gene encodes retinoblastoma protein, which deactivates E2F transcription factors, thereby preventing G1 phase to S phase transition. Mutations in Rb gene are associated with retinoblastoma and osteosarcoma but not with breast or adrenal cancers.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a personal history of malignancy (osteosarcoma, adenocarcinoma) at an early age and a family history of early-onset malignancy (adrenocortical carcinoma). The age of onset and type of malignancies are highly suggestive of the autosomal dominant disorder Li-Fraumeni syndrome.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife 20 minutes after having a seizure. He has had recurrent headaches and dizziness for the past 2 weeks. An MRI of the brain shows multiple, round, well-demarcated lesions in the brain parenchyma at the junction between gray and white matter. This patient's brain lesions are most likely comprised of cells that originate from which of the following organs?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although breast cancers have a tendency to metastasize to the brain, they are not the most common origin of brain metastases. Moreover, cancers of the breast rarely occur in men.

B) INCORRECT:

Colon cancer classically metastasizes hematogenously first to the liver, as venous blood from the colon drains into the portal vein and the hepatic sinusoids, seeding the tumor emboli within the liver parenchyma. Although colon cancers have a tendency to metastasize to the brain, they are not the most common origin of brain metastases.

C) INCORRECT:

Thyroid cancers that spread hematogenously (i.e., follicular thyroid cancer, anaplastic thyroid cancer, and medullary thyroid cancer) predominantly metastasize to the bone and lung but rarely to the brain. Papillary thyroid cancer metastasizes predominantly through lymphatics to the regional lymph nodes; distant metastases from papillary thyroid cancer are uncommon.

D) INCORRECT:

Prostate cancer cells have a high affinity for bone marrow endothelial cells and, therefore, metastasize hematogenously primarily to bone (especially in the lumbosacral spine and pelvis). The prostate is unlikely to be the site of the primary tumor in a patient with brain metastases.

E) INCORRECT:

Renal cell carcinoma most frequently metastasizes to the lungs as the tumor emboli enter the renal vein and inferior vena cava and reach the lungs via the pulmonary artery. Although kidney cancers may rarely metastasize to the brain, they are not the most common origin of brain metastases.

F) CORRECT:

Primary cancers of the lung (particularly small cell lung cancer and adenocarcinoma of the lung) are the most common origin of brain metastases. The 2nd most common origin of brain metastases are cancers of the breast followed by melanoma and cancers of the kidney and colon. Metastatic disease accounts for approx. 50% of all brain tumors.

See “Common origins of cancer metastases” table.
Image Description:

Arrows have been color-coded according to the site of the primary tumor:

Pink: skin cancer
Blue: breast cancer
Green: lung cancer
Orange: pancreatic cancer
Red: colon cancer
Lime: ovarian cancer

The table provides examples of suffixes used to specify the affected organs according to the TNM classification.

G) INCORRECT:

Although melanomas have a tendency to metastasize to the brain, they are not the most common origin of brain metastases.
questions.hint: The junction between the gray and white matter is the typical location for brain metastases, the most common type of intracranial tumors, which visualize as round, well-demarcated intraparenchymal lesions on MRI.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife 20 minutes after having had a seizure. He has had recurrent headaches and dizziness for the past 2 weeks. An MRI of the brain shows multiple, round, well-demarcated lesions in the brain parenchyma at the junction between gray and white matter. This patient's brain lesions are most likely comprised of cells that originate from which of the following organs?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although breast cancers have a tendency to metastasize to the brain, they are not the most common origin of brain metastases. Moreover, cancers of the breast rarely occur in men.

B) INCORRECT:

Colon cancer classically metastasizes hematogenously first to the liver, as venous blood from the colon drains into the portal vein and the hepatic sinusoids, seeding the tumor emboli within the liver parenchyma. Although colon cancers have a tendency to metastasize to the brain, they are not the most common origin of brain metastases.

C) INCORRECT:

Thyroid cancers that spread hematogenously (i.e., follicular thyroid cancer, anaplastic thyroid cancer, and medullary thyroid cancer) predominantly metastasize to the bone and lung but rarely to the brain. Papillary thyroid cancer metastasizes predominantly through lymphatics to the regional lymph nodes; distant metastases from papillary thyroid cancer are uncommon.

D) INCORRECT:

Renal cell carcinoma most frequently metastasizes to the lungs as the tumor emboli enter the renal vein and inferior vena cava and reach the lungs via the pulmonary artery. Although kidney cancers may rarely metastasize to the brain, they are not the most common origin of brain metastases.

E) CORRECT:

Primary cancers of the lung (particularly small cell lung cancer and adenocarcinoma of the lung) are the most common origin of brain metastases. The 2nd most common origin of brain metastases are cancers of the breast followed by melanoma and cancers of the kidney and colon. Metastatic disease accounts for approx. 50% of all brain tumors.

See “Common origins of cancer metastases” table.
Image Description:

Arrows have been color-coded according to the site of the primary tumor:

Pink: skin cancer
Blue: breast cancer
Green: lung cancer
Orange: pancreatic cancer
Red: colon cancer
Lime: ovarian cancer

The table provides examples of suffixes used to specify the affected organs according to the TNM classification.
questions.hint: The junction between the gray and white matter is the typical location for brain metastases, the most common type of intracranial tumors, which visualize as round, well-demarcated intraparenchymal lesions on MRI.
